citations.narrative:
The facility has lost one flamingo and two red junglefowl due to predation within their primary enclosures. On November
21st, 2023, one flamingo was found deceased in its exhibit, with the necropsy report affirming findings consistent with
predation injuries. On December 27th, 2023, two red junglefowl were preyed upon by a hawk, with staff witnessing the
hawk in the chicken exhibit when the deaths occurred.
Ongoing threats due to predation are a concern for all birds housed in their respective enclosures, as these opportunities
contribute to unnecessary stress, injuries, fear, and occurrences for trauma for all of the birds on-hand.
The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds,
and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrective actions were
promptly taken by the facility following each occurrence.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Upon inspection, two boxes of expired antibiotic eye drops were maintained with medications available for use in the
facility’s pharmacy. Additionally, an expired container of urine glucose test strips were kept in a non-human primate
medicine box with another medication currently in use for one Guenon.
Expired drugs and diagnostic tests may lose their strength and the effect of the drugs may be unpredictable, potentially
leading to illness or adverse impact to the animal’s health status. The facility must ensure the availability of appropriate
facilities, personnel, equipment, and services to comply with the provisions of this subchapter.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 18, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility has lost one flamingo and two red junglefowl due to predation within their primary enclosures. On November 
21st, 2023, one flamingo was found deceased in its exhibit, with the necropsy report affirming findings consistent with 
predation injuries. On December 27th, 2023, two red junglefowl were preyed upon by a hawk, with staff witnessing the 
hawk in the chicken exhibit when the deaths occurred.  
Ongoing threats due to predation are a concern for all birds housed in their respective enclosures, as these opportunities 
contribute to unnecessary stress, injuries, fear, and occurrences for trauma for all of the birds on-hand. 
The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, 
and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrective actions were 
promptly taken by the facility following each occurrence. 
2.40(b)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Upon inspection, two boxes of expired antibiotic eye drops were maintained with medications available for use in the 
facility’s pharmacy. Additionally, an expired container of urine glucose test strips were kept in a non-human primate 
medicine box with another medication currently in use for one Guenon. 
Expired drugs and diagnostic tests may lose their strength and the effect of the drugs may be unpredictable, potentially 
leading to illness or adverse impact to the animal’s health status. The facility must ensure the availability of appropriate 
facilities, personnel, equipment, and services to comply with the provisions of this subchapter. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 18, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
